Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with this course compared to others you have taken was
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
How would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other F&ES courses you have taken?
Given the course objectives, the level of intellectual challenge of the material covered was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
How well did the knowledge, skills, and insights gained in this class align with your expectations
What are the strengths and weaknesses of the course and how could it be improved?
What advice would you give to a student considering taking this class
Comments_List: Modeling, due diligence, practical skills / knowledge for forest and ecosystem finance.
Loved the course as I learnt a lot of new exciting material.

I became much more clear about the concept of net present value and gained insight into internal rate of return and discount rate. I learned that it is very possible to navigate the many aspects of valuation.
I developed the ability to assess forests and ecosystems through the lens of finance.
Introduction to new topics, material, and understandings relevant to my interests. Financial analysis and microsoft excel as a financial tool.
Pretty well. It's difficult teaching a finance course at FES, but I thought Dominick did a good job balancing intro finance concepts with some nuance later in the course
Aligned well. Dominick catered to the diverse backgrounds in the class very well.
Well.
The knowledge, skills and insights gained align perfectly with my expectations.
The knowledge, skills, and insights aligned with my expectations.

I would have liked more modeling practice. The second assignment felt like a big leap up from the first assignment. Maybe you could do another iteration of the first assignment before moving onto the second assignment. 


The lectures were dry, mostly because the material was dry. Sitting in a U helped the dynamic considerably. I also would have liked more discussion moments.

I appreciated the input of student presentations but they could have been structured better. I would have gotten more out presenting and out of watching other presentations if we had presented together: one set of summary slides (instead of 3), followed by an analysis of how each of us approached a project differently. Looking over spreadsheet models together to build that presentation would have enhanced my learning.
Slides / presentation could use some more energy, but the concepts and flow of information was great
... improve by providing more brief practice problems for various concepts, especially early in the course.
The strength of the course is teaching students how to understand forests and ecosystems in a financial capacity.  There are no weaknesses in that.

Strengths of the course were in the material covered, readings, and lecture material.  

The course could have been a little more engaging.
One of the few practical courses taught at FES. Should take it if you are remotely interested in forests, ecosystem services, or finance (doesn't have to be all 3).
Please take  an intro finance class at SOM before coming to this class, if you don't have a background in finance.
Take it. The periodic homework project are "real world" and valuable.
Make sure to really understand the time value of money.  And, take advantage of the office hours.
This is a good course for learning financial tools as they relate to forests and ecosystems.
